trans-unit.source: Run the HPC Pack IaaS deployment PowerShell script on a client
trans-unit.target: Run the HPC Pack IaaS deployment PowerShell script on a client

trans-unit.source: computer to deploy a complete HPC Pack cluster in Azure infrastructure
trans-unit.target: computer to deploy a complete HPC Pack cluster in Azure infrastructure

trans-unit.source: services (IaaS).
trans-unit.target: services (IaaS).

trans-unit.source: The script provides several deployment options, and can add cluster compute nodes running supported Linux
trans-unit.target: The script provides several deployment options, and can add cluster compute nodes running supported Linux

trans-unit.source: distributions or Windows Server operating systems.
trans-unit.target: distributions or Windows Server operating systems.

trans-unit.source: Depending on your environment and choices, the script can create all the cluster infrastructure, including the Azure virtual network, storage accounts, cloud services, domain controller, remote or local SQL databases, head node, broker nodes, compute nodes, and Azure cloud service (“burst”, or PaaS) nodes.
trans-unit.target: Depending on your environment and choices, the script can create all the cluster infrastructure, including the Azure virtual network, storage accounts, cloud services, domain controller, remote or local SQL databases, head node, broker nodes, compute nodes, and Azure cloud service (“burst”, or PaaS) nodes.

trans-unit.source: Alternatively, the script can use pre-existing Azure infrastructure and then create the HPC cluster head node, broker nodes, compute nodes, and Azure burst nodes.
trans-unit.target: Alternatively, the script can use pre-existing Azure infrastructure and then create the HPC cluster head node, broker nodes, compute nodes, and Azure burst nodes.

trans-unit.source: For background information about planning an HPC Pack cluster, see the [Product Evaluation and Planning](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/jj899596.aspx) and [Getting Started](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/jj899590.aspx) content in the HPC Pack TechNet Library.
trans-unit.target: For background information about planning an HPC Pack cluster, see the [Product Evaluation and Planning](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/jj899596.aspx) and [Getting Started](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/jj899590.aspx) content in the HPC Pack TechNet Library.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE]You can also use an Azure Resource Manager template to deploy an HPC Pack cluster.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE]You can also use an Azure Resource Manager template to deploy an HPC Pack cluster.

trans-unit.source: For an example, see [Create an HPC cluster](https://azure.microsoft.com/documentation/templates/create-hpc-cluster/), [Create an HPC cluster with a custom compute node image](https://azure.microsoft.com/documentation/templates/create-hpc-cluster-custom-image/), or [Create an HPC cluster with Linux compute nodes](https://azure.microsoft.com/documentation/templates/create-hpc-cluster-linux-cn/).
trans-unit.target: For an example, see [Create an HPC cluster](https://azure.microsoft.com/documentation/templates/create-hpc-cluster/), [Create an HPC cluster with a custom compute node image](https://azure.microsoft.com/documentation/templates/create-hpc-cluster-custom-image/), or [Create an HPC cluster with Linux compute nodes](https://azure.microsoft.com/documentation/templates/create-hpc-cluster-linux-cn/).

trans-unit.source: Prerequisites
trans-unit.target: Prerequisites

trans-unit.source: **Azure subscription** - You can use a subscription in either the Azure Global or Azure China service.
trans-unit.target: **Azure subscription** - You can use a subscription in either the Azure Global or Azure China service.

trans-unit.source: Your subscription limits will affect the number and type of cluster nodes you can deploy.
trans-unit.target: Your subscription limits will affect the number and type of cluster nodes you can deploy.

trans-unit.source: For information, see [Azure subscription and service limits, quotas, and constraints](../articles/azure-subscription-service-limits.md).
trans-unit.target: For information, see [Azure subscription and service limits, quotas, and constraints](../articles/azure-subscription-service-limits.md).

trans-unit.source: **Windows client computer with Azure PowerShell 0.8.7 or later installed and configured** - See [Install and configure Azure PowerShell](../articles/powershell-install-configure.md).
trans-unit.target: **Windows client computer with Azure PowerShell 0.8.7 or later installed and configured** - See [Install and configure Azure PowerShell](../articles/powershell-install-configure.md).

trans-unit.source: The script runs in Azure Service Management.
trans-unit.target: The script runs in Azure Service Management.

trans-unit.source: **HPC Pack IaaS deployment script** - Download and unpack the latest version of the script from the [Microsoft Download Center](https://www.microsoft.com/download/details.aspx?id=44949).
trans-unit.target: **HPC Pack IaaS deployment script** - Download and unpack the latest version of the script from the [Microsoft Download Center](https://www.microsoft.com/download/details.aspx?id=44949).

trans-unit.source: Check the version of the script by running `New-HPCIaaSCluster.ps1 –Version`.
trans-unit.target: Check the version of the script by running `New-HPCIaaSCluster.ps1 –Version`.

trans-unit.source: This article is based on version 4.4.0 of the script.
trans-unit.target: This article is based on version 4.4.0 of the script.

trans-unit.source: **Script configuration file** - You'll need to create an XML file that the script uses to configure the HPC cluster.
trans-unit.target: **Script configuration file** - You'll need to create an XML file that the script uses to configure the HPC cluster.

trans-unit.source: For information and examples, see sections later in this article.
trans-unit.target: For information and examples, see sections later in this article.

trans-unit.source: Syntax
trans-unit.target: Syntax

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE]You must run the script as an administrator.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE]You must run the script as an administrator.

trans-unit.source: Parameters
trans-unit.target: Parameters

trans-unit.source: **ConfigFile** - Specifies the file path of the configuration file to describe the HPC cluster.
trans-unit.target: **ConfigFile** - Specifies the file path of the configuration file to describe the HPC cluster.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [Configuration file](#Configuration-file) in this topic, or the file Manual.rtf, in the folder containing the script.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [Configuration file](#Configuration-file) in this topic, or the file Manual.rtf, in the folder containing the script.

trans-unit.source: **AdminUserName** - Specifies the user name.
trans-unit.target: **AdminUserName** - Specifies the user name.

trans-unit.source: If the domain forest is created by the script, this becomes the local administrator user name for all VMs as well as the domain administrator name.
trans-unit.target: If the domain forest is created by the script, this becomes the local administrator user name for all VMs as well as the domain administrator name.

trans-unit.source: If the domain forest already exists, this specifies the domain user as the local administrator user name to install HPC Pack.
trans-unit.target: If the domain forest already exists, this specifies the domain user as the local administrator user name to install HPC Pack.

trans-unit.source: **AdminPassword** - Specifies the administrator’s password.
trans-unit.target: **AdminPassword** - Specifies the administrator’s password.

trans-unit.source: If not specified in the command line, the script will prompt you to input the password.
trans-unit.target: If not specified in the command line, the script will prompt you to input the password.

trans-unit.source: **HPCImageName** (optional) - Specifies the HPC Pack VM image name used to deploy the HPC cluster.
trans-unit.target: **HPCImageName** (optional) - Specifies the HPC Pack VM image name used to deploy the HPC cluster.

trans-unit.source: It must be a Microsoft-provided HPC Pack image from the Azure Marketplace.
trans-unit.target: It must be a Microsoft-provided HPC Pack image from the Azure Marketplace.

trans-unit.source: If not specified (recommended in most cases), the script chooses the latest published HPC Pack image.
trans-unit.target: If not specified (recommended in most cases), the script chooses the latest published HPC Pack image.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] Deployment will fail if you don't specify a valid HPC Pack image.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] Deployment will fail if you don't specify a valid HPC Pack image.

trans-unit.source: **LogFile** (optional) - Specifies the deployment log file path.
trans-unit.target: **LogFile** (optional) - Specifies the deployment log file path.

trans-unit.source: If not specified, the script will create a log file in the temp directory of the computer running the script.
trans-unit.target: If not specified, the script will create a log file in the temp directory of the computer running the script.

trans-unit.source: **Force** (optional) - Suppresses all the confirmation prompts.
trans-unit.target: **Force** (optional) - Suppresses all the confirmation prompts.

trans-unit.source: **NoCleanOnFailure** (optional) - Specifies that the Azure VMs that are not successfully deployed will not be removed.
trans-unit.target: **NoCleanOnFailure** (optional) - Specifies that the Azure VMs that are not successfully deployed will not be removed.

trans-unit.source: You must remove these VMs manually before rerunning the script to continue the deployment, or the deployment may fail.
trans-unit.target: You must remove these VMs manually before rerunning the script to continue the deployment, or the deployment may fail.

trans-unit.source: **PSSessionSkipCACheck** (optional) - For every cloud service with VMs deployed by this script, a self-signed certificate is automatically generated by Azure, and all the VMs in the cloud service use this certificate as the default Windows Remote Management (WinRM) certificate.
trans-unit.target: **PSSessionSkipCACheck** (optional) - For every cloud service with VMs deployed by this script, a self-signed certificate is automatically generated by Azure, and all the VMs in the cloud service use this certificate as the default Windows Remote Management (WinRM) certificate.

trans-unit.source: To deploy HPC features in these Azure VMs, the script by default temporarily installs these certificates in the Local Computer\\Trusted Root Certification Authorities store of the client computer to suppress the “not trusted CA” security error during script execution; the certificates are removed when the script finishes.
trans-unit.target: To deploy HPC features in these Azure VMs, the script by default temporarily installs these certificates in the Local Computer\\Trusted Root Certification Authorities store of the client computer to suppress the “not trusted CA” security error during script execution; the certificates are removed when the script finishes.

trans-unit.source: If this parameter is specified, the certificates are not installed in the client computer, and the security warning is suppressed.
trans-unit.target: If this parameter is specified, the certificates are not installed in the client computer, and the security warning is suppressed.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.IMPORTANT] This parameter is not recommended for production deployments.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.IMPORTANT] This parameter is not recommended for production deployments.

trans-unit.source: Example
trans-unit.target: Example

trans-unit.source: The following example creates a new HPC Pack cluster using the
trans-unit.target: The following example creates a new HPC Pack cluster using the

trans-unit.source: configuration file *MyConfigFile.xml*, and specifies administrative
trans-unit.target: configuration file *MyConfigFile.xml*, and specifies administrative

trans-unit.source: credentials for installing the cluster.
trans-unit.target: credentials for installing the cluster.

trans-unit.source: Additional considerations
trans-unit.target: Additional considerations

trans-unit.source: The script uses the HPC Pack VM image in the Azure Marketplace to create the cluster head node.
trans-unit.target: The script uses the HPC Pack VM image in the Azure Marketplace to create the cluster head node.

trans-unit.source: The latest image is based on Windows Server 2012 R2 Datacenter with HPC Pack 2012 R2 Update 3 installed.
trans-unit.target: The latest image is based on Windows Server 2012 R2 Datacenter with HPC Pack 2012 R2 Update 3 installed.

trans-unit.source: The script can optionally enable job submission through the HPC Pack web portal or the HPC Pack REST API.
trans-unit.target: The script can optionally enable job submission through the HPC Pack web portal or the HPC Pack REST API.

trans-unit.source: The script can optionally run custom pre- and post-configuration scripts on the head node if you want to install additional software or configure other settings.
trans-unit.target: The script can optionally run custom pre- and post-configuration scripts on the head node if you want to install additional software or configure other settings.

trans-unit.source: Configuration file
trans-unit.target: Configuration file

trans-unit.source: The configuration file for the deployment script is an XML
trans-unit.target: The configuration file for the deployment script is an XML

trans-unit.source: file.
trans-unit.target: file.

trans-unit.source: The schema file HPCIaaSClusterConfig.xsd is in the HPC Pack IaaS
trans-unit.target: The schema file HPCIaaSClusterConfig.xsd is in the HPC Pack IaaS

trans-unit.source: deployment script folder.
trans-unit.target: deployment script folder.

trans-unit.source: **IaaSClusterConfig** is the root element of
trans-unit.target: **IaaSClusterConfig** is the root element of

trans-unit.source: the configuration file, which contains the child elements described in
trans-unit.target: the configuration file, which contains the child elements described in

trans-unit.source: detail in the file Manual.rtf in the deployment script folder.
trans-unit.target: detail in the file Manual.rtf in the deployment script folder.

trans-unit.source: For example files for different scenarios, see
trans-unit.target: For example files for different scenarios, see

trans-unit.source: [Example configuration files](#Example-configuration-files) in this article.
trans-unit.target: [Example configuration files](#Example-configuration-files) in this article.

trans-unit.source: Example configuration files
trans-unit.target: Example configuration files

trans-unit.source: Example 1
trans-unit.target: Example 1

trans-unit.source: The following configuration file deploys an HPC Pack cluster in an existing domain forest.
trans-unit.target: The following configuration file deploys an HPC Pack cluster in an existing domain forest.

trans-unit.source: The cluster has 1 head node with local databases and 12 compute nodes with the BGInfo VM extension applied.
trans-unit.target: The cluster has 1 head node with local databases and 12 compute nodes with the BGInfo VM extension applied.

trans-unit.source: Automatic installation of Windows updates is disabled for all the VMs in
trans-unit.target: Automatic installation of Windows updates is disabled for all the VMs in

trans-unit.source: the domain forest.
trans-unit.target: the domain forest.

trans-unit.source: All the cloud services are created directly in the
trans-unit.target: All the cloud services are created directly in the

trans-unit.source: East Asia location.
trans-unit.target: East Asia location.

trans-unit.source: The compute nodes are created in 3 cloud services
trans-unit.target: The compute nodes are created in 3 cloud services

trans-unit.source: and 3 storage accounts (i.e., _MyHPCCN-0001_ to _MyHPCCN-0005_ in
trans-unit.target: and 3 storage accounts (i.e., _MyHPCCN-0001_ to _MyHPCCN-0005_ in

trans-unit.source: _MyHPCCNService01_ and _mycnstorage01_; _MyHPCCN-0006_ to _MyHPCCN0010_ in
trans-unit.target: _MyHPCCNService01_ and _mycnstorage01_; _MyHPCCN-0006_ to _MyHPCCN0010_ in

trans-unit.source: _MyHPCCNService02_ and _mycnstorage02_; and _MyHPCCN-0011_ to _MyHPCCN-0012_ in
trans-unit.target: _MyHPCCNService02_ and _mycnstorage02_; and _MyHPCCN-0011_ to _MyHPCCN-0012_ in

trans-unit.source: _MyHPCCNService03_ and _mycnstorage03_).
trans-unit.target: _MyHPCCNService03_ and _mycnstorage03_).

trans-unit.source: The compute nodes are created from
trans-unit.target: The compute nodes are created from

trans-unit.source: an existing private image captured from a compute node.
trans-unit.target: an existing private image captured from a compute node.

trans-unit.source: The auto grow
trans-unit.target: The auto grow

trans-unit.source: and shrink service is enabled with default grow and shrink intervals.
trans-unit.target: and shrink service is enabled with default grow and shrink intervals.

trans-unit.source: Known issues
trans-unit.target: Known issues

trans-unit.source: **“VNet doesn’t exist” error** - If you run the HPC Pack IaaS deployment script to deploy multiple
trans-unit.target: **“VNet doesn’t exist” error** - If you run the HPC Pack IaaS deployment script to deploy multiple

trans-unit.source: clusters in Azure concurrently under one subscription, one or more
trans-unit.target: clusters in Azure concurrently under one subscription, one or more

trans-unit.source: deployments may fail with the error “VNet *VNet\_Name* doesn't exist”.
trans-unit.target: deployments may fail with the error “VNet *VNet\_Name* doesn't exist”.

trans-unit.source: If this error occurs, re-run the script for the failed deployment.
trans-unit.target: If this error occurs, re-run the script for the failed deployment.

trans-unit.source: **Problem accessing the Internet from the Azure virtual network** - If you create an HPC Pack cluster with a new domain controller by using
trans-unit.target: **Problem accessing the Internet from the Azure virtual network** - If you create an HPC Pack cluster with a new domain controller by using

trans-unit.source: the deployment script, or you manually promote a VM to domain
trans-unit.target: the deployment script, or you manually promote a VM to domain

trans-unit.source: controller, you may experience problems connecting the VMs in the Azure
trans-unit.target: controller, you may experience problems connecting the VMs in the Azure

trans-unit.source: virtual network to the Internet.
trans-unit.target: virtual network to the Internet.

trans-unit.source: This can occur if a forwarder DNS
trans-unit.target: This can occur if a forwarder DNS

trans-unit.source: server is automatically configured on the domain controller, and this
trans-unit.target: server is automatically configured on the domain controller, and this

trans-unit.source: forwarder DNS server doesn’t resolve properly.
trans-unit.target: forwarder DNS server doesn’t resolve properly.

trans-unit.source: To work around this problem, log on to the domain controller and either
trans-unit.target: To work around this problem, log on to the domain controller and either

trans-unit.source: remove the forwarder configuration setting or configure a valid
trans-unit.target: remove the forwarder configuration setting or configure a valid

trans-unit.source: forwarder DNS server.
trans-unit.target: forwarder DNS server.

trans-unit.source: To do this, in Server Manager click **Tools** >
trans-unit.target: To do this, in Server Manager click **Tools** >

trans-unit.source: **DNS** to open DNS Manager, and then double-click **Forwarders**.
trans-unit.target: **DNS** to open DNS Manager, and then double-click **Forwarders**.

trans-unit.source: **Problem accessing RDMA network from size A8 or A9 VMs** - If you add Windows Server compute node or broker node VMs of size A8 or
trans-unit.target: **Problem accessing RDMA network from size A8 or A9 VMs** - If you add Windows Server compute node or broker node VMs of size A8 or

trans-unit.source: A9 by using the deployment script, you may experience problems
trans-unit.target: A9 by using the deployment script, you may experience problems

trans-unit.source: connecting those VMs to the RDMA application network.
trans-unit.target: connecting those VMs to the RDMA application network.

trans-unit.source: One reason this
trans-unit.target: One reason this

trans-unit.source: can occur is if the HpcVmDrivers extension is not properly installed
trans-unit.target: can occur is if the HpcVmDrivers extension is not properly installed

trans-unit.source: when the size A8 or A9 VMs are added to the cluster.
trans-unit.target: when the size A8 or A9 VMs are added to the cluster.

trans-unit.source: For example, the
trans-unit.target: For example, the

trans-unit.source: extension might be stuck in the installing state.
trans-unit.target: extension might be stuck in the installing state.

trans-unit.source: To work around this problem, first check the state of the extension in
trans-unit.target: To work around this problem, first check the state of the extension in

trans-unit.source: the VMs.
trans-unit.target: the VMs.

trans-unit.source: If the extension is not properly installed, try removing the
trans-unit.target: If the extension is not properly installed, try removing the

trans-unit.source: nodes from the HPC cluster and then add the nodes again.
trans-unit.target: nodes from the HPC cluster and then add the nodes again.

trans-unit.source: For example,
trans-unit.target: For example,

trans-unit.source: you can add compute node VMs by running the Add-HpcIaaSNode.ps1 script on the head node.
trans-unit.target: you can add compute node VMs by running the Add-HpcIaaSNode.ps1 script on the head node.
